so I want to talk a little bit about

let's start off looking at something

when you look at this B it's about this

because they can't see in
Stereo as we go smaller here is a human

smaller again about 10 times smaller
than that is a cell so you could fit 10

human hair so when we look at cells this
is how I really got involved in biology
and science is by looking at living

they look like so if you look at the
cell like that from the immune system
they're actually moving all over the

and it's looking around and when it

finds that little bacterium and it
engulfs it and eats
it if you take some heart cells from an

sit there and beat that's their job
every cell has a mission in life and
these cells the mission is to move blood
around our
body these next cells are nerve cells
and right now as we see and understand
what we're looking at our brains and our
nerve cells are actually doing this
right now they're not just static
they're moving around making new
connections and that's what happens when
we learn as you go farther down this

there and here is a what you see is one

those pollen grains that they're

through their
fragrances I want to talk about
something really ordinary just ordinary
sand I became interested in sand about
10 years ago when I first saw sand from
Maui and in fact this is a little bit of
sand from Maui so sand is about a tenth
of a millimeter in size each sand grain
is about a tenth of a millimeter in size
but when you look closer at this look at
what's there it's really quite amazing
you have Micro shells there you have
things like Coral you have fragments of
other shells you have Olivine you have
bits of the volcano there's a little bit
of the volcano there you have tube worms
an amazing array of incredible things
exist in sand and the reason that is is
because in a place like this island a
lot of the sand is made of biological
material because the reefs provide a
place where all these microscopic
animals or macroscopic animals grow and
when they die their shells and their
teeth and their bones break up and they
make grains of sand things like coral
and so forth so here's for example a
picture of sand from uh from Maui this
is from lahina and when we're walking
along a beach we're actually walking
along millions of years of biological
and geological history we don't realize
it but it's actually a record of that
entire
ecology so here we see for example a
sponge spicule two bits of coral here uh
that's a sea urchin spine really some
amazing stuff so when I first looked at
this I was I thought gee this is like a
little Treasure Trove here I couldn't
believe it and I'd go around dissecting
the little bits out and making
photographs of them here's what most of
the sand in our world looks like these
are quartz crystals and felar so most
sand in the world on on the mainland is
made of quartz crystal and felar it's
the erosion of granite rock so mountains
are built up and they erode Away by
water and rain and ice and so forth and
they become grains of sand there's some
sand that's really much more colorful
these are sand from near the great lakes
and you can see that it's filled with
minerals like pink garnet and green
epidote all kinds of amazing stuff and
if you look look at different Sands from
different places every single beach
every single place you look at sand it's
different here's from Big Sur like
they're little Jewels there are places
in Africa where they do the mining of

where the rivers uh have the sand go

literally looking at tiny Jewels through

unique every Beach is different every
single grain is different there are no
two grains of sand alike in the world
every grain of sand is coming somewhere
and going somewhere it's they're like a
snapshot in
time now sand is not only on Earth but
sand is ubiquitous throughout the
Universe in fact outer space is filled
with sand and that sand comes together
to make our planets and the moon and you
can see those in micrometeorites this is
some micrometeorites that the Army gave

drinking wells in the South Pole and
they're quite amazing looking in these
are the tiny constituents that make up
the world that we live the planets and

sand from all the different
Landings of the Apollo mission that

taking pictures with my
three-dimensional microscopes this was

you can see actually what it looks like
and I do that act in 3D so there you can
see is a left eye view there's a right

right eye view now something's
interesting here this looks very

me look at this hole in the middle that
hole was caused by a micrometeorite
hitting the moon now the moon has no
atmosphere so a microm meteor ATS come
in continuously and the whole surface of
the Moon is covered with powder now
because for four billion years it's been
bombarded by micrometeorites and when
the microm meteorites come in at about
20 to 60,000 miles an hour they vaporize
on contact and you can see here that
that is that's sort of vaporized and
that material is holding this little
clump of little sand grains together
this is a very small grain of sand this
whole thing and that's called a ring of

on the moon look like that and you'd
never find that on
Earth most of the uh of the sand on
earth on on the moon especially and you

that you would look like that you would
see in hakala
um other Sands when these microm
meteorites come in they they vaporize
and they make these fountains these
microscopic fountains that go up into
the and not I was going to say up into
the air but there is no air go uh sort
of goes up and they and these
microscopic glass beads are formed
instantly and they Harden and by the
time they fall down back to the surface
of the Moon they have these beautiful
colored glass fuls and these are
actually microscopic you need a
microscope to see
these and now here's a grain of
sand that is from the Moon and you can
see that the entire crystal structure is
still there this this grain of sand is
probably about three and a half or four
billion years old and it's never eroded

erods away because of water and tumbling

sun has these solar storms and those
that that that's erosion by solar r
ration so what I've been trying to tell

extraordinary if you look closely and if
